title: Type B Aortic Dissection
diagnosis_topic: Acute type B dissection managed medically vs. endovascular repair
setup_script: A 55-year-old man with poorly controlled hypertension presents with sudden sharp back and chest pain. He has no history of Marfan's syndrome or previous aortic disease. He is diaphoretic but alert.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 180/110 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 36.9 C.
Unequal blood pressures in arms, decreased right femoral pulse, neurologic exam intact.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders ECG and troponin

dynamic_flow.reply: CT angiography shows Stanford type B dissection starting distal to left subclavian artery extending to renal arteries; no rupture or malperfusion.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates blood pressure control
dynamic_flow.reply: Administer IV beta-blocker (esmolol) targeting systolic <120 mmHg followed by vasodilator if needed.
Discuss indications for thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) vs. medical management.
Assess renal perfusion, bowel ischemia, lower extremity pulses and spinal cord ischemia.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays blood pressure control
dynamic_flow.reply: Dissection propagates causing renal failure or rupture.
Indicated if malperfusion, rupture, uncontrolled hypertension or rapid expansion.
Importance of lifelong blood pressure control, serial imaging to monitor for aneurysm.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about pain control
dynamic_flow.reply: Use opiates to reduce sympathetic tone.
CT angiography at 3, 6 and 12 months then annually.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of aortic dissection symptoms and differential
Urgent imaging and blood pressure control
Determining indications for TEVAR vs. medical management
